persona.name: Khadija Diallo

occupation.title: Smallholder farmer, informal trader
occupation.organization: Family-run smallholding; member of a local women's cooperative (informal)
occupation.description: Khadija manages a 1.2-hectare mixed farm plot and oversees an extended household. Primary crops: rainfed millet and fonio for household consumption, small rice paddy in a lowland patch, a vegetable garden (onions, tomatoes, okra), and a few rows of cassava. Keeps 3 goats and 1 cow (shared ownership with in-laws) and a small poultry flock. Responsibilities include planning planting with the seasonal rains, managing labor (family labor and occasional day laborers during planting/harvest), seed selection, post-harvest drying and storage, transporting small sacks to the weekly market, bargaining and selling vegetables and millet surpluses. Also intermittently serves as a day laborer on neighboring farms and sews basic clothes for extra income. Skilled at negotiating prices at the market, basic bookkeeping in a notebook, and organizing food distribution within the extended household. No formal contract or social protection; income is irregular and highly seasonal.

persona.residence: Rural village near Labé, Fouta Djallon region, Guinea
persona.education: Completed secondary schooling at a regional lycée in Labé (basic French literacy, algebra, civic education). Attended evening agricultural extension sessions and informal literacy classes offered by a local NGO. Knows Pulaar as first language and functional French for market and administrative interactions.
long_term_goals: Keep her household fed and schooling maintained for her children until each can be self-sufficient.
Improve the small plot productivity so the family has a modest grain reserve and can sell surpluses at market.
Have a simple, sturdy house with a tin roof replaced and improved storage for grain to reduce post-harvest losses.
See at least two of her children complete secondary education and find stable, local jobs.
Pass on agricultural knowledge and the family plot to the next generation in a way that keeps the household together.
Be able to afford emergency medical care without selling livestock or taking onerous debts.
Save enough to visit her brother who migrated to Conakry and repay a small loan taken during a drought year.
Strengthen connections with the women's cooperative to access group savings and small loans.
Reduce the household's vulnerability to seasonal hunger through better seed selection and simple water-harvesting.
Maintain her standing in the community as a reliable neighbor and a calm voice in village discussions.
persona.style: Soft-spoken with a steady, deliberate pace. Speaks Pulaar at home and among neighbors; switches to French when dealing with traders, agricultural agents, or officials, with a Labé-region accent. Uses common religious phrases ('Alhamdulillah', 'Insha'Allah') naturally in speech. Tends to open conversations with questions about others' health and family before stating her own point. Mannerisms: folds hands around a teacup when thinking, taps the ground with her toe when counting money, often clasps a small prayer bead string when anxious. Uses local proverbs and metaphors drawn from farming and weather (e.g., 'the rain is a neighbor—treat it kindly') to explain decisions. Typically dresses in colorful pagne wrappers and a matching headscarf, practical sandals for farm work, and a simple silver wedding ring. When negotiating she smiles politely but keeps eye contact; when upset she becomes quiet, speaks less, but her jaw tightens and she will later address the issue in private. Communicates with a mix of warmth and cautious reserve—friendly but careful to protect her family's resources. When under stress, she repeats practical lists aloud to herself as a calming ritual.

traits: Hardworking: will rise before dawn, sustain long physical days in the field and still do household chores.
Pragmatic: makes decisions based on what will feed the family next month rather than grand plans.
Nurturing: prioritizes children's health and education; known to take in a nephew in a bad season.
Community-minded: participates in shared labor groups and village meetings; helps neighbors in return for mutual support.
Cautious with money: prefers cash savings hidden at home and in a group savings box; dislikes risky loans.
Resourceful: improvises tools, repurposes containers, and finds local solutions when inputs are unavailable.
Patient: willing to wait for a good market day or the right buyer rather than accept a low price.
Stubborn: holds to promises and local norms; resists sudden changes she perceives as risky.
Proud: takes pride in her harvest, her children's manners and her household's cleanliness.
Warm but reserved: easily hospitable, but does not share burdens widely until trust is proven.
Quick to counsel: often gives practical advice to younger women about childbirth, planting and saving.
Sensitive to insults: will avoid confrontation but remembers and will respond later if disrespected.
Curious in a practical way: interested in new seed varieties or storage ideas if they promise clear benefits.

interests: Agronomy practices that reduce post-harvest loss (e.g., drying techniques, storage baskets).
Heirloom seed varieties from her mother that resist local pests.
Practical women's group meetings where savings and tasks are rotated.
Listening to local radio news and agricultural bulletins at midday (Guinean FM stations).
Traditional Pulaar songs and community drums at weddings and naming ceremonies.
Children's schooling and routine (enjoys monitoring homework and teachers' visits).
Cooking community meals on special days and sharing recipes with neighbors.
Simple hand-sewing and mending clothes; interested in better sewing needles and thread.
Learning a new cooking method or spice mix from visiting relatives from the city.
Observing elders' health remedies to expand her home remedies knowledge.
Attending seasonal market days and learning how prices change through the year.
Preserving surplus onions and dried okra in a smoke-dried small corner to last lean months.
Keeping goats healthy and managing small animal breeding.
Saving small sums with the women's cooperative; tracking contributions with a ledger.
Switching to drought-tolerant millet seed if recommended by trusted agriculturist.
Using a mobile phone for money transfer and market price checks when there's a signal.
Making moringa leaf powder for a child with minor nutritional concerns.
Small, practical innovations: a raised seedbed for seedlings, a simple drip bucket to water seedlings.
Learning to make a simple soap to save household expenses and sell small bars at market.
Sharing knowledge with her eldest daughter so the girl can take on some farm management tasks.
likes: Millet porridge (hdl), prepared thick in the morning with a splash of peanut sauce.
Freshly grilled fish when the family can buy it at market, eaten with rice or cassava.
Sweet green tea heavily sweetened and served with toasted peanuts when guests arrive.
Brightly patterned pagnes and practical headscarves that keep hair out of the way when working.
The smell of drying onions and grains in the compound during harvest season.
Early morning breeze while planting; she values quiet dawn hours.
A tidy compound: swept courtyards, stacked firewood, and well-kept children’s clothes.
Being invited to a neighbor's naming ceremony and bringing a small gift of millet.
Listening to the imam's weekly sermon that balances faith and practical advice.
The satisfaction of a successful bargaining exchange at market when she gets a fair price.
Bartering a sack of millet for a few kilograms of sugar and soap in hard months.
Stories from returning migrants about the city that she uses to advise her children.
Seeing young trees she planted begin to bear fruit (mango, guava).
Simple, homemade jewelry—beaded bracelets made by a cousin.
When the community comes together for a collective work day and tasks finish quickly.
Having a small locked chest where she keeps emergency cash and seed money.
Notes from agricultural extension that show simple yield improvements after trials.
That her children greet elders politely and can recite basic prayers.
Older women consulting her for seed-saving tips because of her reputation.
A quiet evening chat with her sister-in-law about the week's events after the children sleep.
dislikes: Loud, chaotic market days when buyers shout and there is little time to bargain fairly.
High-interest informal loans that strip harvest gains; she distrusts moneylenders who charge steep rates.
Plastic bags that blow around and litter fields; she prefers woven sacks for grain.
When young men leave tasks incomplete and blame weather rather than poor planning.
Corrupt officials at distant administrative posts who demand 'a little extra' for simple certificates.
Sour, spoiled millet from poor drying and storage.
Gossip that threatens household harmony—especially rumors about her married daughter.
Unreliable motorbike drivers who damage produce en route to market.
Treatments that promise miracle results but are expensive and unproven.
Being patronized by city-dwellers who dismiss rural ways as backward.
Late delivery of promised agricultural inputs from NGOs.
Medical clinics that lack medicines or send patients to buy everything in town.
When her eldest son returns late the night before a market trip, causing worry.
Being pressured to sell a goat in a lean month rather than keep it for breeding.
Artisans who don't deliver a mended roof on time before the rains come.
favorite_foods_and_drinks: Thick millet porridge with a small spoon of peanut butter.
Rice with a light tomato-onion sauce and occasional smoked fish.
Cassava with spicy okra stew on special days.
Grilled goat meat at major family celebrations.
Baobab juice (bouye) when available during the season.
Sweet green tea with many lumps of sugar for guests.
Roasted groundnuts as a mid-day snack while working the field.
Fresh mango sliced and shared among children during harvest.
Dried okra and smoked fish used to flavor lean-season soups.
A small cup of instant coffee bought in town for rare treats.
market_preferences: Prefers the Tuesday weekly market in the larger nearby town because there are more buyers and better prices.
Sells vegetables in the morning and returns at midday; millet is sold after market traders consolidate orders.
Rides a shared taxi (bush taxi) when carrying sacks to market; prefers a driver she knows for safe handling.
Bundles produce in small, presentable sacks; believes neat presentation helps bargaining.
Prefers female traders for certain goods because they are trusted and often offer credit.
Brings a small scale and bargaining small change in a cloth pouch to make transactions smooth.
Avoids bringing small children to overcrowded market moments when bargaining becomes heated.
Will accept a bit less cash if the buyer pays promptly rather than agreeing to later payments notoriously hard to collect.

beliefs: Family responsibility comes first: elders, children and in-laws are cared for before personal desires.
Hard work and patience will pay off over seasons; there is no substitute for steady effort.
Prayer (daily) gives strength and helps make responsible decisions; faith and farming go together.
Women must be seen as caretakers and managers of the household economy, but capable of important decisions.
Education matters: a child with reading and math skills has more choices than one without.
Migration is risky but sometimes necessary; migrants send vital money and information back home.
Seed saved from the oldest, healthiest plants will protect a household more than cheap commercial seed.
Community cooperation (work groups, shared threshing) is the best insurance against shocks.
Silence about some family issues is better than public airing; reputation is a family's safety.
Loans are tools that must be used carefully; heavy interest is a trap that can break a family.
Health clinics are useful but local remedies work well for many everyday ailments.
A small animal saved for festivals is an important cultural and emotional investment.
Drought is a permanent risk now; prepare every year even if the rains are good today.
Children should learn to help on the farm but should not be overburdened to the point schooling suffers.
Respecting elders and traditional leaders maintains social order and access to communal resources.
Government services are distant and bureaucratic; best to solve most problems locally.
Mobile phones are a blessing—useful for money, information and staying in touch with migrant relatives.
Seeds, water and knowledge are as valuable as cash in bad seasons.
Small, steady savings are more reliable than sudden windfalls that disappear quickly.
One must be cautious about strangers offering 'new methods' without demonstration from trusted neighbors.
Being hospitable—even to modest visitors—maintains social bonds and reciprocal help networks.
Children who know the Koran and local customs gain respect in the community.
It is proper to consult the imam for moral issues and elders for land and family disputes.
Women working together gain more bargaining power with male buyers and can support each other in crises.
Selling the last pregnant goat to meet immediate needs is a bad choice; breed for future stability instead.
A well-kept grain reserve is the best defense against lean months and a way to avoid distress sales.
Public praise for a neighbor's good harvest should be tempered with humility to avoid envy and conflict.
City life has advantages but often corrupts values; children should be cautious if they move to Conakry.
When a child is sick, seek help early, combine clinic advice with a trusted elder's remedy when needed.
Long-term change comes from small adjustments each season rather than radical one-off shifts.
Women's voices deserve space at village meetings even if customs expect them to listen more than speak.
Her family's name and lineage matter; marriage choices should consider character, not just money.
Youth unemployment is a big worry; skills tied to local opportunities (carpentry, tailoring, mobile repair) are valuable.
Good seed and storage sometimes beat a slightly higher market price because they reduce future risk.
skills: Seed selection and saving: identifies healthy millet and fonio heads for next season.
Planting by soil texture and microtopography: knows where to plant rice vs. millet on her plot.
Basic pest recognition and low-cost remedies (ash, hand-picking, simple traps for storage pests).
Traditional post-harvest drying and stacking methods to reduce mold and rot.
Small-animal husbandry: basic goat birthing assistance, chicken care and rotational feeding.
Budgeting in a household ledger: records sales, purchases and remittance amounts in a small notebook.
Mobile money transactions (Orange Money / local equivalent) for remittances and Receiving payments.
Bargaining at market and basic price forecasting: knows when traders from the city will pay more.
Simple carpentry for fences and repairs, using local tools.
Basic sewing and mending for family clothing and small tailoring orders.
Community organizing: coordinates work groups for planting and harvest days, and participates in the women's savings group.
First-aid basics: wound cleaning, recognizing malaria signs, seeking clinic help when danger signs appear.
Interpreting radio agricultural advice and adapting it to local conditions.
Household nutrition adjustments: uses moringa and groundnuts to boost children's iron intake.
Preparing traditional fermented condiments that preserve vegetables longer.

general: Wakes at 4:30–5:00 AM to fetch water, prepare porridge and light fires before dawn prayers.
Counts and recounts money aloud when nervous, then hides small notes in a cloth tied under a mat.
Offers tea promptly to visitors and insists on seating them until they are satisfied.
Is punctual for the weekly women's cooperative savings meeting and keeps a quiet record of who paid and who didn't.
Prefers private conversations for sensitive issues; avoids public disputes.
Sings softly while pounding millet or shelling groundnuts—traditional lullaby tunes passed down from her mother.
Hums when concentrating on difficult tasks like mending a torn roof thatch or repairing a bucket.
Goes to the mosque for Friday prayers and consults the imam informally on community matters.
Tends a small medicinal herb corner and uses those leaves for mild fevers, stomach upsets or wound poultices.
Checks children's schoolbooks in the evening and rewards small improvements with extra porridge or fruit.

morning: Pre-dawn prayer and a short mouthful of porridge.
Takes children to the path where an older cousin walks them to the primary school.
Inspects seedlings and waters the vegetable patch before the sun becomes intense.
Feeds chickens and checks the goats' shelter for signs of predators or illness.
workday: Spends mornings in the fields planting, weeding or harvesting depending on the season.
Returns midday for a simple hot meal prepared with lentils or peanuts, often while discussing prices with her husband.
In the afternoon, she mends tools, sorts grain for sale, or carries a small load to the closest market if needed.
Rarely sits idle: uses the hottest hours for light household chores and care duties.
evening: Prepares evening meal with family—calls everyone to wash hands before eating.
Checks children's homework and sometimes helps with reading in French.
Sits with neighbors after dinner to exchange news, sometimes participates in a short cooperative meeting under a tree.
Prays before sleeping, counts small savings in her head and tucks children in.
weekly: Attends the weekly women's savings group where each member contributes a fixed small amount and rotates who takes the pooled cash.
Visits the larger town market one day each week to sell produce and buy sugar, soap and occasionally cheap cloth.
Attends a village meeting once a fortnight when communal issues arise (water sharing, land disputes).
Visits her elderly mother-in-law once a week to help with heavy tasks and check medicine.

physical_health.general: Relatively robust for her age given physical workload. Has chronic lower back ache from years of bending and carrying sacks of grain. Suffers occasional seasonal malaria—treated with antimalarials; recognizes early signs and seeks clinic when fever high or prolonged.
physical_health.reproductive_health_history: Has had five pregnancies, four live births and one child who died in infancy (diarrheal disease during a particularly bad rainy season). Last birth was three years ago and uncomplicated. Uses spacing by breastfeeding and occasional calendar awareness; would prefer better family planning access.
physical_health.nutritional_status: Household diet heavy on staples; occasional protein from fish and goat. Mild iron-deficiency anemia last measured during a clinic outreach (treated with iron supplements for three months). Children have received most basic vaccinations through outreach campaigns.
physical_health.chronic_conditions: No diagnosed diabetes or hypertension. Experiences occasional migraines during intense work and stress. Mild osteoarthritic pain complaints in knees during rainy season.
physical_health.access_to_care: Primary healthcare clinic 12 km away reachable by shared taxi; occasional outreach from NGOs. Prefers traditional remedies first for mild ailments and clinic for more severe symptoms.

mental_health.general: Psychologically resilient but experiences stress and anxiety linked to finances, crop failure risk and children’s schooling. Sleeps moderately well but has nights of worry during lean seasons.
mental_health.coping_strategies: Seeks social support in the women's group, prays, uses herbal teas to calm nerves, and recounts chores aloud to structure worries.
mental_health.mental_health_risks: High stress during drought years or when a child is ill; minor depressive symptoms (low energy, low mood) after consecutive poor harvests but no formal mental health diagnosis.
mental_health.substance_use: Does not consume alcohol; does not use tobacco or other recreational drugs. Uses sweet tea and, rarely, mild traditional stimulants in social contexts.

medical_history: Childhood illnesses typical for rural life (malaria, measles vaccination through campaigns in later years).
One episode of severe gastroenteritis postpartum many years ago; recovered after local clinic IV and rest.
Regular maternal health check-ups during pregnancies when possible.

relationships.name: Oumar Diallo
relationships.description: Co-manager of the family farm; does heavier tasks—plowing, fetching water for livestock, occasional wage labor in town. Stoic, quiet, respects Khadija's decisions about daily household management but holds final say on larger financial moves. Occasionally distant when city work opportunities arise and a brother returns with 'better ideas'.

relationships.name: Aissatou (eldest daughter)
relationships.description: Attending the regional lycée and helping with farm bookkeeping and younger siblings. Responsible and studious; Khadija hopes she will complete secondary studies and train as a nurse aide or tailor locally.

relationships.name: Mamadou (eldest son)
relationships.description: Works part-time on the farm and occasionally travels to the nearby town looking for carpentry apprenticeships; sometimes impatient with rural pace but helps during harvest season.

relationships.name: Fanta (younger daughter)
relationships.description: In primary school, lively and eager to learn; Khadija tutors her in French at night.
relationships.notes: Khadija worries about early marriage pressures but guards Fanta's schooling closely.

relationships.name: Grandmother Hawa
relationships.description: Lives in the compound; revered elder who advises on planting calendars and herbal remedies. Khadija cares for her and gains respect in the community for this role.

relationships.name: Amadou (brother)
relationships.description: Lives in Conakry; sends occasional advice and is the main recipient of some regular domestic remittances from migrants; Khadija sends small sums to his household when she can; they share news but also occasional friction over expectations.

relationships.name: Women's Cooperative members
relationships.description: A rotating group of 12 women who meet weekly for savings, exchange of seeds and mutual help during harvest. They are Khadija's main social safety net and a place to vent or problem-solve.

relationships.name: Imam Umar
relationships.description: Respected local imam who provides moral guidance. Khadija consults him about community disputes and decisions involving marriage customs.

relationships.name: Market buyer 'Madame Saliou'
relationships.description: A middle-aged trader in the regional market who often buys Khadija's onions and gives small advances on trusted terms when trust is high.

other_facts: Born in the same village where she now lives; married at 18 in an arranged marriage that became affectionate over the years.
Her maiden family name was 'Bah' (maternal line); she still exchanges seeds with her mother's siblings in a neighboring town.
As a teenage girl, she learned seed-saving and weaving mats from her mother and grandmother—skills she uses daily.
She keeps a small, worn notebook where she writes crop yields, market prices and the names of people who owe or lend her money.
In 2012, a severe dry spell reduced her millet yield by half; the family sold two goats and borrowed a sack of rice from the cooperative to survive the lean season.
That lean year taught her to keep a small hidden reserve of seed and cash in a tin beneath the bed.
She once walked for two days to register a child's birth in a distant administrative center because they needed a birth certificate to start school.
She has a scar on her left forearm from a farming accident when a hoe slipped—reminder to teach children tool safety.
Her favorite memory is the birth of her eldest daughter under a baobab tree where women sang as the child arrived.
She learned mobile money through her son and now sends 5,000 GNF monthly to her husband's widowed sister in another prefecture.
She keeps a small sewing kit passed down from her aunt, which she uses to repair clothes and occasionally sew small items for sale.
Has a small drought-tolerant garden patch where she experiments with new seeds recommended by extension workers.
Owns a scratched but cherished enamel tea kettle she uses when guests arrive; it was a wedding gift.
She once mediated a land dispute between two cousins and earned respect as a calm negotiator because she sought elders' counsel.
Her compound has a single solar lamp that charges a phone and lights the kitchen at night; purchased through a group-payment plan.
She has informal arrangements with two neighbors to watch each other's children during peak planting weeks.
Her niece came to live with them for a year after her mother fell ill; Khadija integrated her into the household and taught her to weave mats.
She remembers learning to count money in French at the lycée and still uses French numbers in market negotiations, mixed with Pulaar numerals.
She once took a short training on simple soap-making and still uses the recipe occasionally—saves on soap purchases and small soap bars are sold at market.
Her husband was once offered a seasonal job in a city factory but declined because he feared losing ties to the land.
She has a superstition that planting certain seeds on a Friday brings better yields—an inherited belief though she also trusts agronomy advice.
She keeps a small carved wooden toy for her youngest child made by a neighbor craftsman; it is treasured because it's hand-made.
When a neighbor fell ill, she organized a small collective to cover food and small expenses until the neighbor recovered.
She keeps a folded list of names of those she must contact if a major emergency strikes (neighbor with a motorbike, aunt in the town with a small loan).
She once participated in a participatory seed trial and proudly showed neighbors the trial rows that outperformed older varieties.
She sings lullabies in Pulaar that her children know by heart; these songs include practical lessons (how to sit when sewing, how to hold a hoe).
She fears losing children to early marriage and watches over marriage discussions by favoring school continuation in conversations with suitors' families.
Her compound stores grain in raised clay bins her father-in-law taught her to construct to protect against rodents.
She remembers when the village got its first borehole and how that reduced time fetching water dramatically for women and children.
When it rains heavily she inspects the roof joints immediately; a leaking roof is her acute stress trigger because it risks the seed stores.
She once gave up a promised dowry item to help a cousin's emergency medical visit; it cost her socially but reinforced mutual aid expectations.

Her eldest son once threatened to leave for the city in anger; after a calm family meeting Khadija and Oumar negotiated a short trial apprenticeship in the town so he could test city life without fully leaving.
She has kept a small collection of children's drawings pinned inside her kitchen hut; they boost her spirits during lean seasons.
In community dances she prefers to watch rather than be the center of attention but will join when celebrating a major event.
She is proud that two other women copied her improved onion-curing technique after she demonstrated it at the cooperative meeting.
She once received a small grant through a pilot NGO program to buy a metal grain bin; it reduced storage losses and is one of her most valued assets.
She keeps a quiet dream journal in which she notes small ideas for household improvements—plans to be implemented one by one as cash allows.
She occasionally writes letters (short notes) to her brother in Conakry via a traveling relative when phone credit is low.
Her favorite proverb: 'The one who tills his land with patience harvests with a full heart'—she repeats it to children to teach persistence.
She has a modest personal indulgence: a colorful plastic comb from the town kept in a small drawer and used only on special Sunday hair-braiding days.
She once organized a small children's reading circle under a mango tree to encourage early literacy and received praise from the primary school teacher.
